body:
How long does `rclone lsl` take on the Proton drive destination? Does it take about 17m?

I suspect this is a regression after the reorganization to make very large directories work.

> How long does `rclone lsl` take on the Proton drive destination? Does it take about 17m?

Using version 1.69.3, `rclone lsl --max-age=1h proton:Archive/Documents` took 9 m 37.293 s.   Using version 1.71.1, the command took 9 m 41.976 s.

(Note that I included `--max-age` in the `rclone lsl` command so that it more closely resembled the original `rclone copy` command, but it's not clear to me why `--max-age` is relevant for `rclone lsl` that queries a remote destination.)

I may be naive of how rclone functions internally, but in this particular case, why must `rclone copy --max-age=1h` query the remote destination at all given that it excludes all local source files from transfer to the destination?

> How long does `rclone lsl` take on the Proton drive destination? Does it take about 17m?

Using version 1.69.3, `rclone lsl proton:Archive/Documents` (without `--max-age`) took 17 m 34.581 s.  Using version 1.71.1, the command took 17 m 4.278 s.

How many files does this find? Do they look like the recently modified files?

    rclone lsl --copy-links --max-age=1h --metadata /mnt/zdd/share/Archive/Documents

I looked at protondrive's NewObject API which is what is used by `--no-traverse` and it looks sensible -it finds the directory then calls a specific protondrive API to return just that file.

I wonder if the modtime `--copy-links` isn't working on FreeBSD?

I wonder if somehow that API has slowed down a lot and is returning all the files or something like that.

You could try investigating with `-vv --dump responses` and see if  that gives you any ideas.

> How many files does this find? Do they look like the recently modified files?
> 
> ```
> rclone lsl --copy-links --max-age=1h --metadata /mnt/zdd/share/Archive/Documents
> ```

This command finds no files since none have been updated within the last hour and it completed in 1.208 s using 1.71.1 and in 1.175 s using 1.69.3. 


> I looked at protondrive's NewObject API which is what is used by `--no-traverse` and it looks sensible -it finds the directory then calls a specific protondrive API to return just that file.

What exactly does `--no-traverse` prevent?

> I wonder if the modtime `--copy-links` isn't working on FreeBSD?

How is `--copy-links` relevant?  The performance of `rclone copy` using 1.71.1 is the same with or without `--copy-links`.
 
> I wonder if somehow that API has slowed down a lot and is returning all the files or something like that.

Has the NewObject API changed between rclone 1.69.3 and 1.70.0?  Is this REST API on the Proton Drive server or code linked to the rclone client?

> You could try investigating with `-vv --dump responses` and see if that gives you any ideas.

Command

```
/mnt/zdd/home/derek/bin/rclone-v1.69.3-freebsd-amd64/rclone copy --checkers=12 --copy-links --max-age=1h --metadata --no-traverse --protondrive-replace-existing-draft=true --verbose=3 --dump headers,bodies,requests,responses /mnt/zdd/share/Archive/Documents proton:Archive/Documents
```

 didn't print any HTTP request or response headers or bodies.  Did I specify the `--dump` option correctly?

Note that I observed similar performance of `rclone copy --max-age=1h --no-traverse` using 1.69.3 (fast) and 1.71.1 (slow) on an Ubuntu Server 24.04.3 virtual machine running on Proxmox 9.0.10.  Without `--no-traverse`, rclone 1.69.3 takes much longer to complete the copy, so my guess is that `--no-traverse` is misbehaving for Proton Drive in rclone versions after 1.69.3.

I ran the same copy command using 1.69.3 and 1.71.2 in FreeBSD 13.3 using a local file system destination and noticed no difference in performance, so this issue seems to be particular to at least the Proton Drive remote.

> > How many files does this find? Do they look like the recently modified files?
> > ```
> > rclone lsl --copy-links --max-age=1h --metadata /mnt/zdd/share/Archive/Documents
> > ```
> 
> This command finds no files since none have been updated within the last hour and it completed in 1.208 s using 1.71.1 and in 1.175 s using 1.69.3.

Great. Worth a double check.

> > I looked at protondrive's NewObject API which is what is used by `--no-traverse` and it looks sensible -it finds the directory then calls a specific protondrive API to return just that file.
> 
> What exactly does `--no-traverse` prevent?

Normally rclone will list the source and destination directories in lockstep and match the entries together to see if files need transferring. This is usually the quickest way since listing lots of files is quick (1 API call per 100s of files).

However `--no-traverse` stops the destination listing and checks each file in the source with `NewObject` (1 API call per file). This is usually slower unless you are only transferring a few files in which case it can be much quicker.

Anecdotally from the timings above it looks like your use of `--no-traverse` **is** doing a full traverse of the destination protondrive.

> > I wonder if the modtime `--copy-links` isn't working on FreeBSD?
> 
> How is `--copy-links` relevant? The performance of `rclone copy` using 1.71.1 is the same with or without `--copy-links`.

Fine, we'll ignore that.

> > I wonder if somehow that API has slowed down a lot and is returning all the files or something like that.
> 
> Has the NewObject API changed between rclone 1.69.3 and 1.70.0? Is this REST API on the Proton Drive server or code linked to the rclone client?

There are no changes in the protondrive backend in from 1.69.0 to 1.70.0

However there was a major change in the listing architecture to implement `--list-cutoff`

- 385465bfa sync: implement --list-cutoff to allow on disk sorting for reduced memory use
- 0f7ecf6f0 list: add ListDirSortedFn for callback oriented directory listing
- 08e81f842 list: Implement Sorter to sort directory entries
- 37120ef7b list: add WithListP helper to implement List for ListP backends
- cba653d50 walk: move NewListRHelper into list.Helper to avoid circular dependency
- bff229713 accounting: Add listed stat for number of directory entries listed
- 117f583eb walk: factor Listing helpers into their own file and add tests
- 656e789c5 fs/list: tweak directory listing assertions after allowing // names
 
> > You could try investigating with `-vv --dump responses` and see if that gives you any ideas.
> 
> Command
> 
> ```
> /mnt/zdd/home/derek/bin/rclone-v1.69.3-freebsd-amd64/rclone copy --checkers=12 --copy-links --max-age=1h --metadata --no-traverse --protondrive-replace-existing-draft=true --verbose=3 --dump headers,bodies,requests,responses /mnt/zdd/share/Archive/Documents proton:Archive/Documents
> ```
> 
> didn't print any HTTP request or response headers or bodies. Did I specify the `--dump` option correctly?

You did it correctly, unfortunately the protondrive doesn't use the rclone HTTP Transport like it should so that does not work :-(

> Note that I observed similar performance of `rclone copy --max-age=1h --no-traverse` using 1.69.3 (fast) and 1.71.1 (slow) on an Ubuntu Server 24.04.3 virtual machine running on Proxmox 9.0.10. Without `--no-traverse`, rclone 1.69.3 takes much longer to complete the copy, so my guess is that `--no-traverse` is misbehaving for Proton Drive in rclone versions after 1.69.3.


> I ran the same copy command using 1.69.3 and 1.71.2 in FreeBSD 13.3 using a local file system destination and noticed no difference in performance, so this issue seems to be particular to at least the Proton Drive remote.

What we need to do for the next step is to see whether my hypothesis is correct - that somehow `--no-traverse` is being ignored and a full destination directory scan is happening, or whether something else is going on.

Here is a version of rclone which will debug all the List, NewObject and protondrive API calls. Can you do a failing test with this using DEBUG log `-vv` and send me the full log file please. You can either post it here (clean any personal data from it first) or email it to me nick@craig-wood.com with a link to this issue.

[v1.72.0-beta.9188.3034ecf33.fix-8860-protondrive-no-traverse](https://beta.rclone.org/branch/fix-8860-protondrive-no-traverse/v1.72.0-beta.9188.3034ecf33.fix-8860-protondrive-no-traverse/) on branch [fix-8860-protondrive-no-traverse](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/tree/fix-8860-protondrive-no-traverse) (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

Thank you

@ncw, I emailed you a log file for an "rclone copy" operation of a different set of files than my documents because some of my document file names contain private information.

Despite not transferring a single file, the copy operation using rclone 1.72.0-beta took almost five hours to complete!  Using rclone 1.69.3, this operation completed in just 2.8 s.

Note that the log file contains many instances of suspicious messages like the following:

```
2025/10/21 16:43:53 DEBUG : proton drive root link ID 'Archive/Media': Calling SearchByNameInActiveFolderByID
2025/10/21 16:43:53 DEBUG : proton drive root link ID 'Archive/Media': Calling SearchByNameInActiveFolderByID
2025/10/21 16:43:53 DEBUG : proton drive root link ID 'Archive/Media': Calling SearchByNameInActiveFolderByID                                                      2025/10/21 16:43:53 DEBUG : proton drive root link ID 'Archive/Media': Calling SearchByNameInActiveFolderByID
2025/10/21 16:43:54 DEBUG : proton drive root link ID 'Archive/Media': >NewObject: obj=<nil> err=object not found
2025/10/21 16:43:54 DEBUG : proton drive root link ID 'Archive/Media': >NewObject: obj=<nil> err=object not found
2025/10/21 16:43:54 DEBUG : proton drive root link ID 'Archive/Media': >NewObject: obj=<nil> err=object not found
```

Shouldn't rclone not query the remote at all when it transfers no files?

@derekmahar 
> Despite not transferring a single file, the copy operation using rclone 1.72.0-beta took almost five hours to complete! Using rclone 1.69.3, this operation completed in just 2.8 s.

That was really useful - thank you.

NewObject is called 6397 times but as you said if no objects are transferred then it shouldn't be called at all.

The file names for every single call of NewObject look like directory names not file names which is a big clue.

And all the returns are "object not found" which isn't surprising since `NewObject` finds objects (files) not directories.

With that I managed to replicate and track down the problem :-) Please give this a try

[v1.72.0-beta.9197.a1921101c.fix-8860-no-traverse](https://beta.rclone.org/branch/fix-8860-no-traverse/v1.72.0-beta.9197.a1921101c.fix-8860-no-traverse/) on branch [fix-8860-no-traverse](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/tree/fix-8860-no-traverse) (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

Thank you, @ncw !  You fixed the problem!  rclone 1.72.0-beta.9197 completed the copy operation in just 3.2 s!  This time, `rclone copy --no-traverse` didn't call NewObject at all (or at least it didn't report any calls in the log file).

Was this issue with `--no-traverse` particular to Proton Drive or did it apply to all or other remotes?

Thanks for testing @derekmahar 

I've merged this to master now which means it will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org/) in 15-30 minutes and released in v1.72

If we make another v1.71.x point release we'll put it in that too.
